awd_titl_txt: Seventh International IEEE Conference on  Computational Advances in Bio and medical Sciences (ICCABS) - Travel Awards
awd_abstract_narration:
Computational techniques are drastically impacting the way in which scientific and engineering research are conducted. Impressive advances have been made in different areas including biology, medicine, and drug discovery. Given the great importance of these areas to the society at large, it is essential to advance the state-of-the art in them. Such advances can be made when the scientists from these domains work together and come up with the best possible diagnosis tools, treatment procedures, drugs for various diseases, etc. Even though a number of conferences exist today in the general area of bioinformatics, they focus on one of these three areas to a large extent. This International IEEE Conference on Computational Advances in Bio and medical Sciences (ICCABS) has the goal of bringing together scientists in biology, medicine, and drug discovery and hence serving as a collaboration platform for them. It is expected that these collaborations will result in the solution of some challenging problems.

The requested funds will be used to support the travel expenses of graduate students and post-doctoral fellows (PDFs). These students and PDFs will get to meet experts and listen to their research results. Toward this goal, the plan is to invite a number of keynote speakers and invited speakers. Not only the attending students and PDFs but also other students will benefit since when they return to their schools they will communicate their experience with others in the research group. The conference proceedings will be of great use to students, researchers, and practitioners. Two journal special issues are also planned.

1. Conference Summary

The Seventh ICCABS was held at the Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel, Orlando, FL, from October 19th to 21st, 2017.

 

The conference was a great success as reported by the attendees. Around 60 persons attended the conference. All the talks were well attended and appreciated. The social events were also a big success!

 

Funds from NSF were used to support 18 graduate students who represented 10 different US universities, and one university from Canada.

 

2. Objectives

Computational techniques are revolutionizing the way in which research is conducted in science and engineering. Unsurpassed advances have been made in various areas. This is particularly true in the domains of biology, medicine, and drug discovery. Given that these areas are of utmost importance to the society at large, it is imperative that every effort is made to enable research advances in them. It is not enough if advances are made in these areas in isolation. These communities have to work together to help each other and come up with the best possible diagnosis tools, treatment procedures, drugs for various diseases. Even though a number of conferences exist today in the general area of bioinformatics, they focus on computational biology to a large extent. The proposed conference has the goal of brining together scientists in all the three areas and hence serving as a platform for bridging the research efforts in these areas.

 

3. Conference Topics

The topics of interest to the conference spanned biology, medicine, and drug discovery. Some of the broader topics covered were: Biomedical image processing, Biomedical data and literature mining, Biological Big Data Analytics, Computational genetic epidemiology, Computational metabolomics, Computational proteomics, Databases and ontologies, Data Integration, Gene regulation, Genome analysis, Health Informatics, High-performance bio-computing, Immunoinformatics, Molecular evolution, Population genomics, Sequence analysis, Structural bioinformatics, Systems biology, Transcriptomics, etc.

 

4. Organizational Structure

The steering committee consisted of distinguished scientists: Srinivas Aluru (Iowa State University), Reda A. Ammar (University of Connecticut), Tao Jiang (UC Riverside), Vipin Kumar (University of Minnesota), Ming Li (University of Waterloo), Sanguthevar Rajasekaran (Chair, University of Connecticut), John Reif (Duke University), and Sartaj Sahni (University of Florida).

 

General Chairs of the conference were Sanguthevar Rajasekaran (University of Connecticut) and Shibu Yooseph (University of Central Florida). Program Chairs were Danny Krizanc (Wesleyan University) and Shaojie Zhang (University of Central Florida). Ion Mandoiu (University of Connecticut), Pavel Skums (Genorgia State University), and Alex Zelikovsky (Georgia State University) served as Workshop Chairs. Publicity Chair was Bob Weiner (University of Connecticut). Reda A. Ammar (University of Connecticut) was the Finance Chair. Local Arrangements were handled by Sharma Valliyil Thankachan (University of Central Florida).

 

The Program Committee had 41 members.

 

5. Meeting Format

The Conference was held over a 2.5-day span, following usual Conference conventions. There were two parallel sessions. The technical program included 23 extended abstracts selected by the Program Committee from 45 full submissions received in response to the call for papers. The program also included the 7th Workshop on Computational Advances for Next Generation Sequencing (CANGS) CANGS was organized by Ion Mandoiu, Pavel Skums, and Alex Zelikovsky. The workshop had a total of 24 presentations. There were keynote talks by three distinguished speakers, namely, Jinbo Xu from Toyota Technological Institute at Chicago, Mark Borodovsky from the Georgia Institute of Technology, and Sartaj Sahni from the University of Florida. There were also seven invited talks from established researchers: Pavel Skums (Georgia State University), Jingshan Juang (University of South Alabama), Sumit Kumar Jha (University of Central Florida), Liqing Zhang (Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University), Faraz Hach (Simon Frazer University, Canada), Jaime Davila (Mayo Clinic), and Xianglilan Zhang (University of Waterloo, Canada).

 

6. Outcomes and Dissemination

Authors of accepted papers submitted full papers. These papers were put together to produce the Proceedings for IEEE. These proceedings are available online in the IEEE Xplore digital library. Each participant was supplied with a copy of the Proceedings in a flash memory stick.

 

Out of the full papers accepted for presentation in the conference and the workshop presentations, expanded versions of 20 papers have been invited for two journal special issues (for BMC Bioinformatics BMC Genomics). These two special issues will be edited by the General Chairs, Program Chairs, and the Workshop Chairs. These papers will go through an additional set of reviews. We expect that these special issues will be finalized soon.

 

Special Issues from ICCABS 2016:

I. Mandoiu, S. Rajasekaran, P. Skums, and A. Zelikovsky, Selected articles from the 6th IEEE International Conference on Computational Advances in Bio and Medical Sciences (ICCABS 2016): BMC Bioinformatics, 18(15), 6 December 2017.

 

I. Mandoiu, S. Rajasekaran, P. Skums, and A. Zelikovsky, Selected articles from the 6th IEEE International Conference on Computational Advances in Bio and Medical Sciences (ICCABS 2016): BMC Genomics, 18(10), 6 December 2017.
